title: 109_hr4318
content: The "Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act" terminates prohibitions on expenditures for offshore gas leasing and withdrawals from the Outer Continental Shelf. It revokes restrictions on federal submerged lands for leasing, allowing exploration, development, and production of natural gas. SEC. 10. STATE APPROVAL REQUIREMENT WITH RESPECT TO GAS LEASING. The Secretary cannot grant gas leases within 20 miles of a state's coastline without the Governor's approval. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act requires lease sales to offer at least 75% of available unleased acreage in each planning area for gas leasing. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act mandates that lease sales in each 5-year program must offer at least 75% of available unleased acreage for gas leasing in each planning area. This requirement applies to the current 5-year program and all future programs. SEC. 4. SHARING OF REVENUES. Section 8(g) of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allocate bonus bids and royalties from new Federal gas leases on submerged lands to States. 40 percent goes to the State and 10 percent is available for other uses. Federal gas leases on submerged lands within a State's seaward boundaries established under section 4(a)(2)(A) allocate 40% to the State and 10% for the Low-Income Home Energy Assistance Program. Existing gas leases also pay a portion of bonus bids and royalties to the State. Existing Federal gas leases on submerged lands within a State's seaward boundaries established under section 4(a)(2)(A) allocate a percentage of bonus bids and royalties to the State. The payments to the State increase over three fiscal years after the enactment of the Outer Continental Shelf Natural Gas Relief Act. The Natural Gas Relief Act increases payments to States for Federal gas leases on submerged lands over four fiscal years, starting at 10 percent and increasing by 10 percent each year up to 40 percent. The Natural Gas Relief Act increases payments to States for Federal gas leases on submerged lands over four fiscal years, starting at 10 percent and increasing by 10 percent each year up to 40 percent. For leased tracts partially within a state's seaward boundaries, bonus bids and royalties are subject to specific percentages based on the surface acreage within those boundaries. The Natural Gas Relief Act increases payments to States for Federal gas leases on submerged lands over four fiscal years, starting at 10 percent and increasing by 10 percent each year up to 40 percent. Bonus bids and royalties from leased tracts within seaward boundaries are subject to specific percentages based on surface acreage. Definitions for existing and new Federal gas leases are provided. The Natural Gas Relief Act establishes new federal gas lease terms and increases payments to States for Federal gas leases on submerged lands. It also amends the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act to define extended state seaward boundaries. The Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to define extended state seaward boundaries using specific maps for each outer Continental Shelf region. SEC. 5. NATURAL GAS-ONLY LEASING. Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act is amended to allow the Secretary to issue leases for natural gas and associated condensate production, with regulations defining natural gas, condensate, and oil, establishing lessee rights and obligations, and outlining procedures for lease compliance. The amendment to Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows the Secretary to issue leases for natural gas and associated condensate production, with regulations defining natural gas, condensate, and oil, establishing lessee rights and obligations, and outlining compliance procedures for oil deposits discovered during exploration or development. All provisions of this Act or other Federal laws that apply to oil and natural gas leases also apply to natural gas-only leases authorized under this subsection. The amendment to Section 8 of the Outer Continental Shelf Lands Act allows the Secretary to issue natural gas-only leases, with regulations applying all provisions of this Act or other Federal laws that apply to oil and natural gas leases. At the request of the lessee, development under existing oil and gas leases can be restricted to natural gas and associated condensate only. The Secretary may issue natural gas-only leases before June 30, 2007, without amending the program for 2002-2007. The Secretary may restrict development under a lease to natural gas and associated condensate only. They can issue natural gas-only leases without amending the outer Continental shelf leasing program for specific time periods. The Secretary can include provisions for natural gas-only leases in the outer Continental shelf leasing program for the 5-year period starting in 2007, regardless of any previous draft proposals.
